segments.text: Because had this revolution not been, and had it not taken place, I imagine today I'd probably be in Mexico.
And we all would have missed an opportunity.
Now, if you had stayed in Mexico and there had been no revolution, presumably you would have been part of the upper class.
Probably.
But there was a revolution, and there has been and were revolutions since then.
Anyway, we don't know what destiny would have had in store for us over there, but we are fortunate.
the revolution took place, and we left Mexico.
And we're most grateful.
Neither you nor your parents have ever given any thought of going back to Mexico?
No.
We're most grateful for the blessings that we received.
Have you ever been back just to visit?
Oh, yes.
You've been back to your old hometown?
I went once to the hometown.
I was there for a very short while.
I saw places that brought back memories of my infancy.
And, of course, the place has changed considerably.
And it was just out of curiosity that I went back to this particular place.
Was the family home still there?
The family home had been confiscated by the government for, I guess, an unpayment of taxes.
We had several...
plantations that belonged or would have belonged to my mother by descent and distribution that nobody ever cared to make a claim for.
We were too happy in the United States.
The country around here, around El Paso, is it very different in physical appearance from the part of Chihuahua you were from, or is it similar?
Similar.
In Santa Barbara, the mining town was dry and arid.
El Paso has similar mountains, similar climate.
However, El Valle is an oasis.
a lot of vegetation.
This country that we passed over was mostly farmlands, farms and ranches scattered from El Valle and Peral, north to Delicias.
Now coming through Nica was
quite an arid experience, an arid portion of the country.
But we don't see it that way.
We just looked forward in making an exodus out of a turmoiled country.
How did your family happen to come to Chihuahua, that is your ancestors, in the beginning?
I don't know.
They say that one of my ancestors had been a general in the army, the Porfirio Diaz regime.
But that's hearsay.
Now, from my mother's side, they were all farmers from
in the area around El Valle in Peral.
And they had come into the area, do you remember in what years they came into the area?
I have no idea.
But they must have come in there as pioneers.
Pioneers, they must have.
At one time.
Right.
From the south.
Or, we have no idea.
We used to hear about
our grandfather on the paternal side being the general in the Diaz army.
We don't know, I don't know whether that was braggadocious or not.
However, my experience since I was able to cope with reasoning power
I don't remember of any incident that was not related to, like I said, when my father left.
He left us in Santa Barbara.
It was terrible.
That must have been right in 1910 or 1911 when he first left?
Sometime around that age.
How did he hear that he had to get out of town?
Oh.
Everybody knew as soon as the revolution started breaking here, there, and built pots of resistance here.
Everybody knew that a cientfico was the arced enemy of the revolutionary element.
And it was a class struggle and a vicious one.
The proletariat had venom and vindictiveness and wrath upon this class of people.
So that's why Father left.
He left this small mining town in Santa Barbara.
I think he had been Presidente Municipal there, or had been affluent with the government.
And he knew that if he stayed there, he would be one of the first individuals that reprisals would be taken against him.
And that's why he left as far as Canada.
Get a whole country between.
That's right.
Did anyone ever really bother your mother and the small children?
Oh, yes.
They used to be the proletariats that would come around the household and would sing dirty and nasty songs about the revolution and about people in Mexico that were scared to death.
And they would sing.
We had neighbors that would come in and sing these songs.
And they said, now that the revolution is here, now you are going to get it.
and songs of threats and of intimidation.
And we were constantly in fear.
Every time a band of different rebels would come into the city, like I told you, they would use that tank as a target.

Several times after the battles were over, we could hear a knock or expect a knock at the door of the house and open the door and a bunch of soldiers and horses, horseback, very unusual looking characters with their guns and cartuchetas all over them and the officer knocking down at the door.
They would say, all right, boys, come on in.

some troops would go in there bayonets guns look for the enemy and we the officer would on numerous occasions said we heard that you were shooting at us from this area right sometimes mother and the children would be out on the sidewalk and in the evening conversing
All of a sudden, we'd hear turmoil coming down the street, a mob of people hollering.
And we would holler and say, the Madaristas are coming.
And we would all go in doors, lock ourselves.
We had a great big door for this one.
And one night, Mother was visiting with ladies on the street, on the sidewalk there, sitting down, taking air.
When we heard this commotion coming down the street and we rushed in, I locked the door.
I got my thumb cut in between me.
That's why we had one thumb larger than the other.
Oh, my goodness.
It was smashed.
And, of course, little incidents.
But we could expect that a daily occurrence.
We wanted to get out of there.
Did you hear from your father by mail or any other way during this period?
No way.
One night, or in the early hours of the morning, here he comes with his big, big wee child.
All right, get ready.
We're leaving in the morning.
And that was the first time in nearly two years your mother had even known he was alive, for sure, I guess.
I guess so.
That's the first night I was able to recognize my father.
That's the first mental impression.
So it must have been a year or two that I was growing up and had no conception of what my father looked like until that night that I saw him.
I knew he was my father because mother told me.
And of course, the affections.
The rest of the kids.
I said, oh, they had this great big hat.
disguised as a proletariat.
No time to lose.
He must have been a very brave man to come back in.
Right.
For all of you that way.
I don't know how he got there, but he had this wagon, a team of mules, and off he took.
Going through the back roads.
Yes, it was a very interesting experience.
Well, when you got to the States, did any of you speak English?
I was the guest speaker at the White House.
LBJ took a liking to me, I don't know why, and he would invite me to the White House to be the guest speaker.
And he named me on several committees for the purpose of creating and organizing and building a new society.
And I spoke at the White House one night about a little incident that took place here in El Paso with me while I was going to school.
I went to Alamo School.
After I became of age, I wasn't old enough to go to school.
I think I had to wait some two years, maybe a year, I don't know.
Anyway, I went to Alamo school, and the lady there, the teacher, Ms. Witt, taught us children how to raise our little two fingers.
Anytime we wanted to go to the restroom and use these magical words, may I be excused.
So she was a bilingualist.
She told us what it meant.
One day Mrs.
Whip becomes ill, and they have a substitute, a beautiful blonde girl with blue eyes.
Oh, she was beautiful.
And in due time, I raised my little fingers.
Teacher, my biscus.
She turned around and says, if it's absolutely necessary.
Well, not being a bilingualist, I did not know what if it's absolutely necessary meant.
So I took it and presumed that my permission had been denied.
So five minutes later, I raised my two little fingers again and said, teacher, may I have an excuse?
And I got the same answer, if it's absolutely necessary.
I sat down.
And about five minutes later, I raised my fingers again and asked for the excuse.
And she again said, if it's absolutely necessary.
Well, ladies and gentlemen, by that time, it had become apparent that it had been necessary.
Since thereafter, the kids in school changed my nickname
from Kiko to something else which was very embarrassing.
But the reason I'm relating that, this is what I was telling it, is because
We did not possess the ability of understanding.

And we needed at that time, as it's needed now, a course or something that would teach the children going for the first time to an American English-speaking school at least the rudiments of the English language.
It would be very obvious.
It was quite obvious.
Now, do you remember when it was that you really began to learn English?
How many years of school did it take?
Well, the first, probably six months after I went to school, I started learning English.
Not only in school, but by singing these little songs that the children get in the first grade.
And learning, how do you do, Will?
How do you do, Fly?
This is Will.
This is Fly.
This is Mel.
We learned all flat in first grade, but probably six or seven months after you're in school.
But I learned English a little faster than those children.
Not because I heard it at home.
but because I heard it downtown, selling papers and shining shoes and learning that the mystery word for sir or senor was mister.
And mister shine, mister paper, mister this, and gradually you start building a vocabulary of what you hear from other people.
So it was beyond the school experience then.
In working, you needed the language.
And that provided an extra.
It was both in school, but mostly the most effective teacher that I had was in the streets selling newspaper.
Paper, mister?
Paper, mister?
He would say, no, thank you.
No.
Well, no and no is the same.
And gradually, you start building a vocabulary, a street vocabulary.
Tramp, that was about the second word I learned.
And of course, you marvel with amazement why I should learn the word tramp.
Well, the fellow who would give us his newspapers.
Somehow or other, the rest of the kids, instead of calling the circulation manager,
or the distributor, he would count out the papers.
And he says, here.
And they called that man who would give the papers out Tramp.
Because as I later found out, that the Tramps coming in and out, trenching people of the cities, would get jobs also selling papers.
But they were older than we were.
Consequently, they would be the distributors.
And they would, people would call them tramps because they had floated into the city of El Paso.
I guess that's why.
Well, when you were arrested, you spoke pretty good English by that time, didn't you?
By that time, yes.
I was about 12 years old, and I was going to Bailey, Bailey School.
That's right.
I started in Bailey School in the fifth grade.
And as you remember,

First, we lived at 1011 East 3rd, and we're going to Alamo School, clearly a school wherein no English was utterly spoken until, uttered or spoken in until you got to the second and third, fourth grade.
So your first year in school was taught in Spanish?
No, in English, but the ability to simulate and learn English
was lacking because most... None of the students could speak English.
None of the students.
We'd go in the playground and we'd holler and joke and speak to one and the other in Spanish.
On the second grade in San Jacinto School, we moved to an environment where more English and American people were living at that time.
What was the name of...
I forgot.
And consequently we had more of a intermingling with the Anglo-American children and we started playing and calling a bat and a football and give me this and give me that.
And most of the, I guess, the vocabularies was built in the playgrounds or in communications with other children.
I don't think a vocabulary, actually the vocabulary was being built in the classrooms, though we had the words and spelling and whatnot.
But I think the ability to adopt ourselves into thinking and speaking English came by associating with other English-speaking children.
The Spanish-speaking children that you were growing up with, how many of them would you say had come to get away from the revolution?
How many of them were refugees?
A lot of them.
Calderon families, Rocha family.
Mr. Rocha had taken up his residence on San Antonio Street on the 1100 block, and he had been a general in Diaz's army.
And most of the, there was an organization that was later started here called the Casino Social Mexicano, the Mexican casino.
And all of them were of affluent people from Mexico.
And they established quite a cultural club.
And they gave and fiestas.
parties, gatherings, social gatherings for the Mexican refugee.
And Mrs. Terrazas would meet Mrs. Gonzalez and say, well, what did you get here?
And so on.
It was really, El Paso was a colony for the refugees, the affluent and the poor.
Well, our period of transition from an affluent to a poor family came or was
brought about in Mexico because we left as a broken down bankrupt affluent.
And when we got here, we had nothing but the... You had had lands in Mexico.
Yes.
But you just let them go.
Right.
And we had no resources.
here in the United States, and we did not bring with us any resources because we didn't have any.
Was this true of most of the affluent refugee families, or did some of them manage to come in with... A lot of the families, the refugees of the affluent class, came in with their dollars and cents.
And waiting for a time to get acclimated,
Some of them remained and some of them went back.
When did they begin going back, those that went back?
I don't think they went back until after 1932 because, or during the Depression, because Mexico was in a turmoil with different revolutions one right after another.
And if I had been fleeing from the revolution because I was an effluent, I certainly wouldn't have gone back until there was a different form of government.
But of course, as you know, the revolutionary party or the revolutionary element gained control of Mexico in the present time.
They celebrate the victory of the revolution.
And all of them
that have become affluent were at one time a revolutionary element, let's put it like that, or their parents were.
Some of these new fortunes that have been built have been built or have been acquired by individuals, children of the revolution.
So if we had been affluent and had funds with which to go back to Mexico, I don't think her family, brothers and sisters, would have cared to go back to Mexico.
Did you have any family that did stay in Mexico?
That is, on your- Oh, yes.
We had a lot of the family, members of the family that stayed in Mexico.
My uncle, who had been Presidente Municipal of the city of Chihuahua, remained in Mexico in Chihuahua.
He lost his shirt.
He was involved in mining operations, money-making deals in property and whatnot, but he went broke.
And most of the African people who remained in Mexico went broke.
Their properties were confiscated.
Some of them were executed.
Your uncle's family now is his children.
Are they still in Mexico?
left Chihuahua and she came to reside here with relatives and she married here in El Paso, married an American citizen.
And she had three children, a girl and two boys.
One of the boys is a professor at the University
Texas.
His name is Provencio.
You may know him.
In what department is he in?
I don't know.
I think he's in the mathematics department.
Jesus, not Jesus.
What is his first name?
Anyway, he is a professor and he was grandson of my uncle.
His other two
her other two children.
are in Mexico, one of them decided to become an American, a Mexican citizen, though he was born here, they had dual nationality, and he took it upon himself.
His name is Marcus, and Jesus Provencio, and what is the name of the girl?
She decided to be an American, and she was working one time at the American Embassy in Mexico City.
So there were different choices made at that time.
Now, the Matas remained mother's relatives.
They all remain in Mexico, the Mata family.
Let me draw this out just a minute.
I can get a clearer idea if I draw.
See if I draw a picture.
There's your mother and your father.
Could I scoot up here a little bit?
Yes, by all means.
Okay.
I got it.
Okay.
And let's see, your father's name was... My father's name was Francisco.
Francisco... Galvan.
G-A-L-V-A-N. And your mother's name was... Susanna.
Marta.
M-A-T-A.
Galvan, by marriage.
And then here are you and your brothers and sisters, and these would be... All right, your uncle, your father's brother stayed in Chihuahua.
Yeah, Guadalupe Galvan.
That's Guadalupe.
And he was married to... A Cejas, Mercedes Cejas.
And they were effluent to say hus.
I don't know how to spell say hus.
C-E-J-A-S, I'm guessing.
Say.
Say hus?
Say hus.
Let's see.
I don't know.
S-E-Y, say hus.
Yeah.
S-E-Y or S-E-I, I think, J-A-L-S, Cejas.
No, never mind the L, just J-S. S-E-I-J-A-S, Cejas.
Now, there was a very prominent attorney in Juarez and in Chihuahua by the name of Cejas.
Mm-hmm.
related or a brother of Mercedes.
And the Cejas were a very affluent both cultural and economical family in Chihuahua.
So my uncle married a very well-to-do family.
Did they remain well-to-do after the revolution?
I don't think so.
But as far as you know, they stayed in Mexico.
Yeah.
Then they had these children you were mentioning who were... Marcos.
Marcos, who stayed in Mexico.
Right.
Jesus.
Jesus.
Who was a professor at UTEP.
And I don't remember the girl's name.
And she also is an American citizen?
An American citizen.
When did these children come to the States?
Do you remember?
Yes, they were educated in the States.
And all the children were born in the States.
Oh.
It was the... Guadalupe and Mercedes did come to the United...
Wait a minute.
Guadalupe and Mercedes...
Remained in Mexico, and they had a daughter here.
Oh, I missed it.
Okay, I missed...
They just had the one daughter.
That's right.
And she...
Okay.
I missed a generation.
Yeah.
Okay, they had a daughter.
Whose name?
Do you remember her name?
Mercedes.
Mercedes.
Who married... Provencio.
Provencio.
In El Paso.
Provencio, what was his last name?
That's his last name.
Oh, that's his last name.
Mr. Provencio, I don't remember his last name.
And he was from El Paso.
He was from El Paso.
And then their children were educated in the States.
Were born here in El Paso and were educated in the States.
I think he, Marcus, went to University of Colorado, both of them.
And I don't know where she went to Laredo here.
And then when they became of age, Marcus went to Mexico and took up his Mexican citizenship.
And he remained in the United States as a professor and used to work.
He had quite a hard time getting his professorship because he
had one time moved to Juarez and was involved in a, mind you, an engineer, electrical engineer, going to Juarez and becoming a TV repairman.
And I said, Marcos, I mean, Chuy, you're wasting your talents.
What are you doing in Mexico?
You know you're not a Mexican citizen.
You know you were born in the United States, and you have a college.
You have a degree in, I think, an electrical engineer from Colorado University.
What are you doing in Mexico there?
I said, you better move back to the United States right away.
You're illegally in Mexico.
You come over here, and we'll push you.
What are you doing there?
I can't understand an educated man like you.
So I was influential in getting him back here in the United States.
This was Jesus.
That's right, the professor right now.
Did he ever say why it was that he went back?
No.
I think he was influenced by Mother or Marcus.
Marcus had a very good position, an engineer in Mexico City.
They're very nice people, and of course we never have had any disagreement at all, but a political view, and I suggested to Marcus that he quit associating himself in Mexico.
Not because I hate Mexico, because I thought it was wasting his opportunity.
that he had become educated in the States.
And then going down there and becoming an engineer of a radio station that wasn't paying him anything.
And just because he was an engineer and had the title of an engineer, he's got a title here of an engineer.
Now he's got the title of a professor.
And he, of course, realizes that I was right in advising him.
Did you think there's really more opportunity for a person in this country than in Mexico?
Oh, surely.
The integrity of the nation, the integrity of our law, the opportunities now that are being offered.
I have always
told my constituents that we are worth two Anglo-Americans because we have two different cultures.
And that we had not been paid accordingly because it was our fault.
And it was our fault because we did not exploit or use our talents to the full degree and to the fullness of our capacities.
And that we were to show the industry that we were by linguists and by culture and dedicated
to our tasks and we would be able to show them that we were worthy of certain considerations.
And of course I think presently there has been the swinging of the pendulum that have recognized the individual for what he's worth and not what he used to be nor the color of his skin
nor the color of his eyes.

How much of this do you think is partly a matter of time, that with so many of the people who came from Mexico having come just at the early part of this century, that maybe, you know, it's the story of so many other people who have come from so many other places, that it's a matter of perhaps the first generation of adjustment and then the real potential being recognized.
Right.
Well, it has here in the United States.
through the efforts of the government, Equal Employment Opportunity Council, of which I was the chairman, and the own minority groups to be able to show that they have the talent.
And eventually, the discrimination of classes, discrimination of races,
are fast disappearing.
Oh, I can remember here when they had signs, no Mexicans allowed in public places.
And I can remember when Bowie High School was refused a ROTC unit.
I went and spoke to the school board about it.
And it has come to pass that what I said, and that's why the president gave me this recognition, that it has come to pass that all the prophecies and all our dreams are gradually becoming realities.
But it wasn't a reality that had to come overnight and quickly.

It was a reality that came into and is continuing to be carried on forward because of the, first of all, the, let's call it, if we may, the tolerance that the majority had or had given, finally, the minority.
Well, they call it tolerance and we call it a vested inherent right that we had.
But call it what it may, it has gradually developed into the recognition of the talents of the minority.
Well, when you first
When you first came to El Paso, was there that much discrimination against people of Mexican origin?
It was when you first, in the very beginning.
Oh, in the very beginning, yes.
In the very beginning, there was this discrimination that we did not become aware of it until we started growing up and finding out.
And just like I said in the White House, and like I told them here just recently, why were there two different outhouses?
Never heard that for El Paso.
Oh, yes.
In El Paso, in the Washington Park, a public place where the children of the Ale inhabitants would go on a Sunday afternoon to play.
There would be an outhouse, a red brick building for whites, for Mexicans, and colored.
And this from the very early period?
Early period, as soon as I started to be able to find my way to the Washington Park by riding a streetcar.
And this applied to the children of the very affluent who had come during the Revolution?
Everybody without any...
They were not according to themselves.
They were not Mexicans.
They were Spanish.
Well then, which restroom did they use?
They had to use a restroom that said for Mexicans or blacks.
And I, of course, I'm a great kidder, public speaking.
I said, I don't know what was wrong with our insides.
Were they white?
The Anglo-American perfumed inside?
Do you have any idea when this distinction arose?
Because, after all, El Paso was settled by Spanish Mexicans.
And, you know, like, they were here first.
And the Anglos were really latecomers.
Have you ever read, I'm sure you have, the Diary of the Pilgrims by Mr. Fleming?
No, I haven't.
I'll write it down.

Mr. Fleming speaks and writes of the coming of the Pilgrims, and he writes a diary of everything that took place, including the mild standage and his army of twenty men, and how they finally settled in Plymouth.
And the pilgrims went out and investigated the surrounding territory and the characteristics of the territory.
They found a bunch of sand mounds on the hill tops.
They wondered what it was and they started digging into it and they found that it contained some vegetable matters.
a vegetable that they had never seen before.
They took this vegetable and removed it in their ears and they found out it had a cob and little grains.
They took it into the Mayflower and started investigating it and finally someone got the idea that it must be edible and they cooked it and they found out that it was corn.
They named it corn.
That was an introduction of corn.
So they went back to this mountain, looked into them, and they found it full of ears of corn.
So they start taking them into the Mayflower, when upon here comes a bunch of Indians shooting bows and arrows at them.
And they said they were not welcomed in the United States or in this country by these savages.
So they started building a cantonment fortification.
They got through.
And then one Sunday, little did they know why the vindictiveness of the Indian towards them and their hate.
And one Sunday afternoon after church services, here comes a buxom Indian, knocks at the door of the cantonment and shows himself that he has no weapons.
Miles Standage opens the doors and they aim the guns, the shotguns they had at this fellow.
Then in perfect English he says, welcome to America.
